abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education for All (EFA)
            Project for Nepal were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate; Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory; and borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: International Development Association
            (IDA) has supported education in Nepal for over three
            decades, and has constantly evolved its approach to
            developing the sector based on the lessons learnt from its
            projects. In designing the last program of the current
            series, School Sector Reform Plan (SSRP), it has continued
            to integrate and build on the lessons learned from the
            implementation of past programs. From the perspective of
            wider application, the EFA program provides some important
            overall lessons. Specifically, four key lessons emerge from
            the successful implementation of the EFA program: (i) a
            Sector Wide Approach (SWAp) that supports the
            Government's own program and relies on Government
            structures for implementation can be an effective tool to
            harmonize partner support, strengthen sectoral management
            capacity and reduce transaction costs; (ii) high level
            political commitment is critical to achieve difficult
            reforms as is bureaucratic buy-in; (iii) effective
            communication, specifically on progress of reforms can play
            a critical role in ensuring sustainability of reforms; (iv)
            participatory processes to engage communities and mobilize
            beneficiaries can be a powerful means to achieve results.
            Adequate capacity building is crucial to enable effective
            decentralization, particularly at the village and community
            levels. The reforms introduced under the EFA program
            successfully decentralized administrative and financial
            authority to local community bodies, i.e. the School
            Management Committees (SMCs). To be truly meaningful, this
            reform needs to be accompanied with strong capacity support
            to ensure that the SMCs play their roles effectively.
            Capacity support needs to be continuous and focused.
            Balancing incentives to students with incentives to schools:
            To date, strategies to enhance educational outcomes of the
            disadvantaged have focused on increasing access through
            provision of incentives such as scholarships.
